posts.title: Joy in Mudville: A First Edition of Casey at the Bat Joins the Rare Book Division Collections
posts.text: Just in time for the 2018 All-Star Game: a recent addition to the Rare Book Division, one of the most famous poems in American folklore. See photos, history, and details.

posts.title: Antonio Ricardo: South America’s First Printer
posts.text: Learn about this 16th century trailblazer, and his rare works that are part of the NYPL collections.

posts.title: Gart der Gesundheit: The 1487 Edition of The Garden of Health
posts.text: Enjoy a look at a recent addition to the Rare Book Division's collection, a "materia medica" from the 15th century.

posts.title: New in the Rare Book Division: The Second Book Printed in South America
posts.text: A rare find has found its way to the NYPL Rare Book Division: The 1585 printing of "Confessionario para los Curas de Indios".

posts.title: New in Digital Collections: The Bay Psalm Book
posts.text: Recently, The New York Public Library digitized in its entirety one of its great treasures, the 1640 printing of The Whole Booke of Psalmes Faithfully Translated into English Metre.

posts.title: O Tannenbaum: Or, a Brief History of the Christmas Tree
posts.text: Let's take a break from the season's commotion in order to better appreciate the history of this most festive conifer.

posts.title: New York on the Front Line: The Black Tom Island Explosion, July 1916
posts.text: On Sunday morning, July 30, 1916, at 2:08 a.m., one of the worst terrorist attacks in American history took place at Black Tom Island, New Jersey, a shipping facility located in New York Harbor.

posts.title: Coming Soon: The Hunt-Lenox Globe, in 3D!
posts.text: The New York Public Library received a generous grant from the Samuel H. Kress Foundation to scan the globe using 3D imaging technology.  The project was undertaken in conjunction with the Lazarus Project, an organization that provides historical researchers access to advanced imaging technology.

posts.title: Remembering (the Hardly Trivial) Sam Houston: Rare Texana at the Library
posts.text: April 21 is the anniversary of the Battle of San Jacinto. As any grade school student in the Lone Star State will proudly tell you, the leader of the Texan forces was Samuel “Sam” Houston, a.k.a. the President of the Republic of Texas. He is well-represented in NYPL's collection of Texana.

posts.title: Spies Among Us: World War I and The American Protective League
posts.text: In the wake of the United States’ war declaration against Germany on April 6, 1917, dozens of extralegal vigilance organizations such as the Knights of Liberty, American Rights League, Boy Spies of America, American Defense Society, Sedition Slammers, National Security League, and the Terrible Threateners sought to ensure Americans’ full participation in the war effort, often through measures of intimidation, harassment, surveillance, and outright violence.

posts.title: United States v. "The Spirit of '76"
posts.text: During World War I, the making of movies—even seemingly pro-American films—could be a dangerous proposition, given the wartime hysteria so prevalent on the U.S. home front.  Case in point:
